statement.text: An iliac conduit is a surgical technique where a prosthetic graft is anastomosed to the common iliac artery via retroperitoneal approach to provide large-bore access for endograft delivery when native iliac vessels are inadequate.

explanation.intuition: When the natural highway (iliac artery) is too small or damaged for the delivery truck (endograft system), you build a temporary on-ramp (conduit) that can be converted to a permanent exit ramp (anastomosis to external iliac or femoral).
explanation.key_insight: The conduit serves dual purpose: (1) safe access for device delivery, and (2) subsequent anastomosis site for graft limb or native vessel reconstruction. It converts an endovascular challenge into a planned hybrid procedure.
explanation.technical_details: Technique: Oblique flank incision or lower midline, retroperitoneal exposure of common iliac artery, proximal/distal control, 8-10mm Dacron graft sewn end-to-side to anterior common iliac. Device delivered through conduit. After deployment, conduit either anastomosed to external iliac (if diseased) or oversewn and external iliac restored. Alternative: aortic conduit via transperitoneal approach when bilateral iliac disease.

procedural_details.anastomosis: End-to-side to anterior common iliac artery
procedural_details.completion: Anastomose to EIA, ligate and oversew, or use as permanent bypass

clinical_pearls: Plan conduit position to avoid tension during device delivery
Consider leaving conduit as permanent iliac bypass if EIA diseased
Retroperitoneal approach minimizes ileus and recovery time
